Gardevoir.overview:
• Mega Gardevoir sets itself apart from other Fairy-type threats like Tapu Lele with its access to Pixilate-boosted Hyper Voice and Trick Room. These moves allow Mega Gardevoir to function as an offensive Trick Room user that can simultaneously apply pressure to two foes.

  • Mega Gardevoir's ability to threaten problematic foes to Trick Room teams like Amoonguss also differentiates it from other Trick Room users like Cresselia and Mimikyu.

  • Mega Gardevoir is also capable of providing unique team support. Trace copies foes' abilities, and this can come in handy against foes like Landorus-T and Salamence, or scouting foes' abilities. The moveset can also be adjusted to employ utility moves like Will-O-Wisp, Taunt, and Destiny Bond.

  • As a Trick Room user, Mega Gardevoir's low physical bulk and high Speed can be detrimental. Mega Gardevoir is easily overwhelmed by a myriad of common physical attackers even when running bulk investment, and it is slower than foes like Tapu Bulu and Porygon2 under Trick Room. This leaves Mega Gardevoir somewhat reliant on its teammates to effectively function, and this combines with the fact that Mega Gardevoir takes up a Mega slot to make it somewhat of a Pokemon that must be built around.

  • Gardevoir has little to do against Steel-types like Mega Metagross, Aegislash, Heatran, and Ferrothorn due to them resisting its STAB combination.

  • While Mega Gardevoir may seem to be able to run a fast, offensive attacker set, its susceptibility to priority moves and the presence of faster threats like Kartana, Tapu Koko, and Mega Gengar make any sets other than Trick Room hard to justify over other threats like Tapu Lele.

Trick Room.description:
• Trick Room allows Mega Gardevoir to take an effective countermeasure against faster teams, which it would easily be taken down against. Bulk investment and Mega Gardevoir's general offensive power aid its ability to set up Trick Room against a considerable portion of the metagame.

  • Hyper Voice nets sizable damage on many neutral foes despite the lack of much investment due to Mega Gardevoir's high Special Attack and a boost from Pixilate. It is the most effective option for Mega Gardevoir to deal with Dragon-types like Mega Salamence.

  • Psychic hits a number of important foes that are resistant to Pixilate-boosted Hyper Voice, such as Mega Charizard Y, Amoonguss, and Nihilego for high damage. Psyshock is an alternative to OHKO the latter two and generally hit specially defensive foes like Snorlax harder at a cost of slightly less power.

  • Mega Gardevoir's role as a Trick Room setter, access to a spread attack, and frailty entice attacks from foes often. Protect therefore makes a good option to temporarily guard it from offensive pressure.

  • The given EV spread ensures that Mega Gardevoir survives two Earthquakes from Jolly Landorus-T and a Sludge Bomb from Mega Gengar. 36 Special Attack EVs allow Mega Gardevoir to benefit the most from its Special Attack-boosting nature.

  • An alternative Relaxed nature works if Mega Gardevoir will have to survive Double-Edge from Mega Salamence and avoid the 2HKO from Adamant Landorus-T's Earthquake.

  • 36 Speed EVs can be run with a Modest or Bold nature so that Mega Gardevoir can outspeed everything up to Jolly Choice Scarf Landorus-T with Tailwind support.

  • Various slow physical attackers can work with Mega Gardevoir to take down each other's checks while running rampant when Trick Room is active. Incineroar is a notable partner for easing Mega Gardevoir's attempt to set up Trick Room by weakening foes with Intimidate and using Fake Out.

  • Other slow teammates like Snorlax, Tyranitar, and Araquanid can take advantage of Trick Room. All of them can run viable countermeasures to deal with Steel-types and specially defensive foes.

  • Landorus-T is a viable teammate that also appreciates Trick Room due to its middling Speed. It offensively checks some of Mega Gardevoir's biggest checks like Mega Metagross, Aegislash, and Heatran.

  • Tailwind is also a viable option to support Mega Gardevoir. Offensive teams often lack a proper way to deal with Gardevoir and therefore the Speed boost from Tailwind makes it notoriously difficult to deal with. Zapdos is a viable setter due to its ability to threaten Celesteela and keep Calm Mind Tapu Fini in check, while Kartana is a good teammate thanks to it threatening Steel-types with Sacred Sword and specially defensive foes.

All-out Attacker.description: This set aims to maximize Heatran’s offensive potential. In the third moveslot, Flash Cannon acts as a single-target STAB move that checks Fairy-types such as Tapu Lele and Gardevoir. Hidden Power Ice checks Landorus-T and Mega Salamence; it is quite useful for Heatran to hold a Shuca Berry for the former. Solar Beam should be used with Grassium Z to check Water-types such as Tapu Fini and Suicune. Firium Z provides a strong single-target Fire-type attack. The EVs let Heatran survive Landorus-T’s Earthquake with Shuca Berry; use 252 SpA / 252 Spe with another item. Additionally, bulky spreads can be used with speed control such as Tailwind and Trick Room.

Substitute.description: Substitute is easy for Heatran to set up thanks to its many resistances, and helps it avoid super effective attacks such as Earth Power in the Heatran mirror. Leftovers compensates for the HP lost to Substitute, although Shuca Berry gives Heatran the flexibility to survive attacks such as Landorus-T’s Earthquake without its use. The EVs ensure Landorus-T’s Rock Slide cannot break Heatran’s Substitute. Fake Out users such as Mega Kangaskhan pair well with this set, as they improve its ability to set up Substitute safely. Tapu Bulu’s Grassy Terrain can mitigate damage from Earthquake and recovers the health Heatran loses to Substitute.

Bulky Attacker.description: Aegislash is one of the best Steel-types in the format thanks to Stance Change shifting it between extreme bulk and offensive at will. Wide Guard is often appreciated given how common spread moves are, but Shadow Sneak can be used if Aegislash's team isn't weak to them or already has a user of the move. Ghostium Z is the preferred item, as it's not reliant on a foe activating it and reduces the damage received from Knock Off. Speed is minimized to reduce the chance Aegislash has of receiving damage in its vulnerable Blade forme after attacking. Hydreigon is a good partner, as it has perfect defensive synergy with Aegislash.

Substitute.description: Substitute makes a great fit for Aegislash, as it's both difficult to break through in Shield forme and helps Aegislash maintain offensive pressure in its vulnerable Blade forme. A two-attack approach is common, although Ghost having such great neutral coverage allows Flash Cannon to be dropped for utility in the form of Wide Guard or Toxic. Not minimizing Speed is preferred on Substitute Aegislash, as this lets it use Substitute and Toxic before base 60 Speed Pokemon. Fake Out users such as Mega Kangaskhan make good teammates for this set, as they’re able to create opportunities for it to use Substitute.

3 Attacks + Protect.description: Electric Terrain boosting Electric attacks and low defensive stats incentivize Tapu Koko to go for an all-out offensive set, and Electrium Z and Life Orb provide the greatest increase to damage output while letting Tapu Koko retain the ability to switch moves. Volt Switch is useful to switch out of dangerous situations, though Taunt stops speed control such as Tailwind and Trick Room. Dazzling Gleam is quite weak, but is useful in being both a spread and secondary STAB move. Hidden Power Ice primarily takes care of Landorus-T. Pelipper makes for a good teammate, as it can check Grass- and Ground-type foes which care little for Electric attacks.

Choice Specs.description: Choice Specs maximizes Tapu Koko’s consecutive damage output, allowing Tapu Koko to deal a great deal of damage even when pivoting out with Volt Switch. Dazzling Gleam is often preferred in the third moveslot for providing a STAB spread move, despite being weak. Hidden Power Ice is an alternative for foes such as Landorus-T, although using it disallows the use of Hidden Power Fire to hit the likes of Ferrothorn. Grass Knot has a chance to OHKO troublesome foes such as Tyranitar and Swampert. As this set lacks Protect, Intimidate users such as Landorus-T and Salamence can be valuable to help Tapu Koko remain on the field for longer.

Tapu Lele.overview:
Tapu Lele is a powerhouse in VGC 2018, throwing out extremely powerful Psychic Terrain boosted STAB attacks, and supporting its team by blocking priority with its Terrain (most notably Fake Out, which is extremely useful early in the game). However, Tapu Lele isn't a particularly bulky or fast Pokemon, and it's unable to deal with every Steel-type at once.

Below are some sample sets. These sets are likely to be standard, but they will be expanded upon and updated as the metagame progresses.

Offensive.description:
• Psychic is Tapu Lele's powerful STAB of choice, while Moonblast deals more damage when Psychic Terrain is gone and smashes through Dark-types.
  • Thunderbolt deals good damage to Celesteela, while Hidden Power Ground slams Heatran. Shadow Ball deals good damage to Aegislash (though watch out for Weakness Policy) and can pick off Mega Metagross under Tailwind or Trick Room. Taunt can be good against Trick Room set up.
  • Psychium Z lets Tapu Lele unleash its powerful Z-Psychic, which is powerful enough to OHKO fast Assault Vest Landorus-T. If you're especially desperate to take out Amoonguss, it also OHKOes through Payapa Berry.
  • Life Orb lets Tapu Lele deal more consistent damage. Most notably, it gives Modest Tapu Lele a 75% chance to OHKO maximum HP Heatran.
  • A Modest nature gives Tapu Lele more power, but a Timid nature is useful for outspeeding Landorus-T that lack a Choice Scarf, and Modest Mega Charizard Y. Bulkier spreads are viable if using Psychium Z.
  • Pay attention to when Psychic Surge comes up against other Pokemon with activation abilities, as this will reveal what Pokemon is faster. This is especially handy for revealing if Landorus-T has a Choice Scarf if using Timid Tapu Lele.
  • Consider pairing Tapu Lele with Pokemon that defeat Steel-types, since Tapu Lele can't cover them all with one moveset. Celesteela, Heatran, Mega Metagross, Aegislash, and Focus Sash Bisharp are important ones to consider defeating.
  • Intimidate support comes in handy to help patch up Tapu Lele's mediocre Defense stat.
  • Mega Metagross deserves special mention as a teammate, since Psychic Terrain gives Zen Headbutt a ton of power, and Psychic Surge reveals if Landorus-T has a Choice Scarf or not.

Choice Scarf.description:
• Choice Scarf allows Tapu Lele to blast through fast threats with Psychic. Moonblast is great for OHKOing Mega Salamence and Hydreigon.
  • Dazzling Gleam gives Tapu Lele a spread attack, which can clean up late game despite being relatively weak.
  • Hidden Power Ground 2HKOes Heatran, while Thunderbolt does reasonable damage against Celesteela.
  • Note that because of how activation abilities work, leading with Tapu Lele will often reveal that it has a Choice Scarf if sent out against slower Pokemon with activation abilities such as Tapu Koko or Choice Scarf Landorus-T.
  • A Timid nature ensures that Tapu Lele outspeeds Jolly Choice Scarf Landorus-T, but a Modest nature does give it more power.
  • Steel-types such as Celesteela, Mega Metagross, and Heatran are especially problematic since Tapu Lele locks itself into moves, so consider pairing Tapu Lele with Pokemon that give them trouble.

Z-Move.description: Tapu Bulu’s high Attack stat and access to powerful moves in Wood Hammer and Superpower make it well able to fire off exceptionally strong Z-Moves. Even outside of this role, though, Wood Hammer is often Tapu Bulu’s move of choice, as it’s boosted by Grassy Terrain and the recoil is less of an issue thanks to Terrain recovery and the ability to use Horn Leech later in battle. Good teammates are often those that appreciate Grassy Terrain reducing the damage of Earthquake. Heatran and Tyranitar are particularly good examples of this, as they further appreciate the removal of Water-types and Low Kick Mega Kangaskhan.

Assault Vest.description: Tapu Bulu’s bulk in combination with recovery from Horn Leech and Grassy Terrain makes it an excellent Assault Vest user. The EVs and nature maximize recovery from Grassy Terrain while letting Tapu Bulu take Modest Mega Charizard Y’s Heat Wave and OHKO it back with Rock Slide and outrun uninvested Milotic. Tapu Bulu has limited alternatives for offensive coverage, although Stone Edge is an option over Rock Slide if you’d prefer to trade accuracy for a better chance to OHKO bulky Fire-types. Drizzle Politoed makes a good partner for mitigating Tapu Bulu’s Fire weakness, and Ground-weak allies such as Mega Mawile appreciate Grassy Terrain.

Calm Mind.description: An immunity to status through Misty Terrain makes Tapu Fini an excellent Calm Mind user. The spread survives Landorus-T’s Tectonic Rage, and OHKOes back with +1 Muddy Water, as well as Timid Tapu Koko’s Thunderbolt. Leftovers and Sitrus Berry are viable alternative items, although rarely heal as much as a 50% Berry does over the course of a battle. Intimidate users such as Mega Salamence and Landorus-T make excellent partners, as they can reduce the damage Tapu Fini receives from physical attackers. The aforementioned Pokemon are also useful in order to check Grass- and Electric-types, respectively, with their STAB moves.

Choice Specs.description: Choice Specs boosts Tapu Fini’s initially underwhelming damage output to acceptable levels, making it more immediately threatening and reducing the need for support from teammates. This set utilizes a straightforward EV spread and has few alternate move choices; Hydro Pump, Ice Beam, and Haze are all possibilities, but often weaker than those listed on the set. Cresselia makes a good partner, as it appreciates foes like Heatran being removed, and can use Helping Hand to boost Tapu Fini’s damage output further. A Heatran of your own has in common with Cresselia the ability to check Amoonguss, which walls Tapu Fini’s attacks.

Trick Room.description: Cresselia is one of the bulkiest Trick Room setters and therefore one of the most reliable. Ice Beam is a common coverage move for picking up the OHKO on Landorus-T and Mega Salamence. Alternatively, while Icy Wind might seem paradoxical on a Trick Room set, utilizing them both allows an incredible degree of flexibility in speed control. The last slot is largely filler; Helping Hand is generally useful, Hidden Power Ground hits troublesome Steel-types like Heatran, and Toxic deals with bulky foes like Porygon2. Psychium Z allows the use of Z-Trick Room to stop Taunt, or a big attack in Z-Psychic, and also limits damage from Knock Off.

Calm Mind.description: Calm Mind remains a strong option despite an uptake in the use of Toxic. Psychic is the preferred STAB move for its superior power, but Psyshock allows Cresselia to hit more specially defensive foes hard. The given nature and EVs aim to maximize Cresselia’s mixed walling capabilities, although a spread such as 244 HP / 108 Def / 68 SpA / 4 SpD / 84 Spe can be adopted to help beat foes such as Mega Salamence by outspeeding and 2HKOing Adamant variants with Icy Wind and making Jolly Salamence’s Double-Edge a 3HKO. Mega Charizard Y makes a good partner to deal with Steel-types and boost the healing of Moonlight with sun.

Venusaurite.description: After Mega Evolving, Mega Venusaur gains exceptional defensive stats and an ability that indirectly removes two of its weaknesses in Thick Fat, making it a great late-game wincon once its checks have been removed early-game. The given EVs allow it to survive two Life Orb-boosted Earthquakes from Landorus-T and Mega Gardevoir’s Psychic, maximize the benefit of a Modest nature, and let it outspeed base 130s under Tailwind. Removing threats like Tapu Lele and Mega Salamence is key to Mega Venusaur’s survival, so Steel-types such as Aegislash and Heatran are immensely helpful in this respect.

Sun Attacker.description: Chlorophyll Venusaur outpaces the entire unboosted metagame when paired with Drought Mega Charizard Y. Grass Pledge is an option when Mega Charizard Y is using Fire Pledge, as their combined use creates a sea of fire that removes 12.5% of both foes’ health for four turns. That said, Energy Ball is the more flexible alternative. Sleep Powder is great support, albeit inaccurate and stopped by Electric and Misty Terrain. Hidden Power Ice lets Venusaur check foes such as Landorus-T and Mega Salamence, which sun teams typically have issues with. Venusaur struggles against Heatran, so ensure you have a check to it such as Landorus-T or Terrakion.

Charizard.overview:
Mega Charizard Y is a dangerous spread attacker, dealing massive damage with Sun-boosted Heat Waves. Unlike most Fire-types, Water-types have trouble with Mega Charizard Y because of Drought and Solar Beam. However, Mega Charizard Y heavily relies on the sun to deal damage, and it has an unfortunate weakness to Electric-type attacks, and a 4x weakness to the ever common Rock Slide.

Below is a sample set. This set is likely to be the standard, but it will be expanded upon and updated as the metagame progresses.

Drought Attacker.description:
• Heat Wave is Mega Charizard Y's powerful spread attack, while Solar Beam has no charge up turn under the sunlight, letting Mega Charizard Y slam Water-types like Rotom-W and Milotic.

  • Overheat is insanely powerful, OHKOing threats such as Tapu Lele and fast Assault Vest Landorus-T, though at the cost of halving Special Attack. Flamethrower can be used if Mega Charizard Y just needs to OHKO regular Landorus-T.

  • Hidden Power Ground is Mega Charizard Y's best way around Heatran, 2HKOing bulky varients at worst, and OHKOing fast offensive Heatran.

  • Modest gives Mega Charizard Y the most power, but Timid can be used to outspeed Jolly Landorus-T and Timid Tapu Lele.

  • If Politoed, Pelipper, Tyranitar, or Alolan Ninetales are seen in team preview, consider holding off on Mega Evolving right away, since if these switch in at the right time, Mega Charizard Y becomes much easier to check, especially if Pelipper or Politoed bring the rain.

  • Rock Slide is a serious problem for Mega Charizard Y. Consider Intimidate support to help it take weaker ones at least once. Wide Guard support can work well too, letting Mega Charizard Y stay in the field in the face of Rock Slide.

  • Mega Charizard Y also hates Electric-type Pokemon such as Tapu Koko and Thundurus. While Lightning Rod support can be helpful, it doesn't stop Discharge. Consider bringing Electric-type resistances to switch into.

  • Mega Charizard Y does great with Pokemon that use Earthquake thanks to its Ground-type immunity, and it also helps out against Water-types thanks to Drought and Solar Beam.

Raichu.overview:
• Despite its underwhelming stats, Raichu possesses a solid niche in VGC due to its expansive pool of support options and access to Lightning Rod, which lets it be an excellent support partner for Water-types like Tapu Fini and Pelipper and Flying-types like Mega Charizard Y.

  • Raichu's good Speed allows it to quickly disrupt foes in various ways with support moves like Fake Out and Encore, letting its teammates safely set up boosts or Tailwind reliably.

  • These near-exclusive traits set Raichu apart from other Lightning Rod users like Mega Manectric, Alolan Marowak, and Togedemaru.

  • While Raichu easily handles any relevant Electric-types thanks to Lightning Rod, its horrid bulk leaves it unable to reliably take hits without relying on Focus Sash or its teammates' Intimidate. The fact that Raichu has a hard time justifying Protect in its moveset further worsens its problem with survivability.

  • Raichu's offensive presence is meager, as it struggles to deal significant damage without resorting to a Z-Move and struggles to effectively deal with common Electric-type checks. Therefore, Raichu functions the best when running a dedicated support set.

Fast Utility.description:
• Raichu's superb Speed stat makes it one of the fastest Fake Out users, and it can provide its teammate a turn to safely make a move.

  • Encore locks a foe into the same move for three turns, potentially forcing them to repeatedly use an unfavorable move or switch out.

  • Thunderbolt is the strongest STAB move, while Volt Switch is slightly weaker but can be used to take advantage of forced switches and generate momentum.

  • Hidden Power Ice targets Landorus-T, but note that unboosted Hidden Power Ice is too weak to OHKO Landorus-T from full HP.

  • Protect guards Raichu from attacks for a turn and let its teammates handle a problematic foe.

  • Feint breaks foes' Protect or Detect, leaving them vulnerable to Raichu's teammates. It also proves to be useful with breaking Focus Sashes and securing the success of a Z-Move.

  • Nuzzle paralyzes non-Ground- and Electric-type foes and reduces their Speed, leaving them vulnerable to slower and powerful attackers like Incineroar and Landorus-T.

  • Focus Sash allows Raichu to survive a potential KO and generally aids it by improving its chances of survivability. Electrium Z can be used to provide Raichu with more offensive presence by letting it use Gigavolt Havoc. While the damage output may not seem great at a first glance, Gigavolt Havoc is capable of doing massive damage after teammates like Tapu Koko used Discharge to activate Raichu's Lightning Rod.

  • Ensure that Raichu is providing sufficient support for its teammates. This means Fake Out should be used against problematic foes in the beginning and faster threats and Choice Scarf users should be taken down or crippled by Nuzzle. Scouting a foe with Protect and locking them into a wrong move with Encore can also provide good setup opportunities for Raichu's teammates.

  • Pokemon that are weak to Electric-type moves, such as Mega Charizard Y, Gyarados, Braviary, and Pelipper, can be paired with Raichu due to its Lightning Rod. They also can switch into Ground-types aimed at Raichu thanks to their immunity to Ground. Tapu Fini and Azumarill also appreciate Lightning Rod.

  • Various Pokemon with setup options can take advantage of free turns that Raichu generates with Fake Out, Encore, and even full paralysis after Nuzzle. Setup sweepers like Mega Salamence and Gyarados can set up without fearing Electric-type moves while discouraging Earthquake from foes, while slower threats like Incineroar can effectively combat faster foes after Raichu paralyzes them.

Bulky Utility.description:
• Raichu's high Speed allows it to make other Fake Out users like Incineroar and Mega Kangaskhan flinch. Fake Out's general utility proves to be useful for Raichu's teammate, as they gain a free turn to safely set up.

  • Nuzzle paralyzes non-Ground- and Electric-type foes, crippling their Speed. Electroweb is an alternative option to provide a general speed control against two foes at the same time, and it can provide speed control even when Misty Terrain is active. Both of them are viable utilities for Raichu to utilize as support options, and they can't be prevented with Taunt.

  • Volt Switch lets Raichu pivot out and switch to another teammate and preserve momentum.

  • Feint removes the effect of Protect and Detect from a foe, leaving them vulnerable to Raichu's teammates. Especially if Raichu's teammate is a Z-Move user, Feint helps ensuring that a foe will take massive damage from Z-Move after their protection is broken.

  • Knock Off rids foes of an item, and it is useful for getting rid of foes' items and scouting possible Z-Crystals. Ridding foes like Cresselia, Gastrodon, and Tapu Fini of their item and removing pinch Berries also greatly reduces their longevity and overall defensive presence.

  • This set is dedicated to make Raichu as bulky as possible with an Assault Vest and heavy investment in HP. The given EV spread allows Raichu to survive -1 Adamant Mega Kangaskhan's Double-Edge from full HP, survive Ludicolo's rain-boosted Hydro Vortex, and avoid the 2HKO from Timid Mega Charizard Y's Heat Wave. 76 Speed EVs and a Timid nature allow Raichu to outspeed neutral-natured base 100 Speed Pokemon.

  • Pokemon like Mega Charizard Y, Tapu Fini, Gyarados, and Pelipper enjoy Raichu's Lightning Rod and ability to render the likes of Tapu Koko and Zapdos ineffective. They also notably force Ground-types like Landorus-T to refrain from using their STAB moves.

  • Practically any Pokemon with mediocre Speed appreciates Raichu's useful speed control and Fake Out that improves their matchup against faster foes. Tailwind setters and setup sweepers also enjoy the various utility options Raichu can provide. Slower and bulkier Pokemon like Incineroar and Landorus-T can take advantage of Raichu's speed control and hindrance of various physical walls, while Mega Salamence and Gyarados can have significantly better setup conditions with Raichu's support. Their Intimidate also improves Raichu's durability further by compensating for Raichu's pitiful Defense stat, while Assault Vest improves Raichu's matchup against special attackers.

Support.description: Friend Guard Clefairy has a niche as a redirector in its ability to reduce the damage its partner receives from spread damage. The EVs make Timid Mega Charizard Y’s Heat Wave and Landorus-T’s Earthquake a 3HKO. Icy Wind is a good speed control option, although Trick Room teams can make use of After You thanks to Clefairy’s low Speed. Heal Pulse is often chosen for its synergy with Friend Guard, especially on PerishTrap teams, where Shadow Tag Mega Gengar and Gothitelle must remain healthy to maintain the trap. Setup sweepers such as Quiver Dance Volcarona and Dragon Dance Mega Salamence also appreciate Clefairy.

Ninetales-Alola.overview:
• Alolan Ninetales boasts the ability to check popular metagame titans like Landorus-T, Mega Salamence, Pelipper, Ludicolo, and Gastrodon.

  • Furthermore, having the combination of Aurora Veil and Snow Warning enables it to easily support its team by reducing the damage done to them. This may be useful to make walls like Celesteela even harder to take down or to make it even easier for Pokemon like Snorlax to set up.

  • Although Alolan Ninetales checks multiple common Pokemon, it is also checked by many common Pokemon, including Aegislash, Mega Charizard Y, and Tyranitar. Furthermore, the latter two can easily change the weather, making it harder for Alolan Ninetales to set up Aurora Veil.

  • A mediocre Special Attack stat makes it difficult for Alolan Ninetales to do much damage to any Pokemon it doesn't hit super effectively.

Hail Setter.description:
• Blizzard is Alolan Ninetales's go-to STAB move, never missing in hail and dealing damage to both opposing Pokemon.

  • Freeze-Dry allows Alolan Ninetales to deal super effective damage to Water-type Pokemon, a trait that is especially handy against Pelipper, Ludicolo, and Gastrodon. Furthermore, as it's a single-target move, it gives Alolan Ninetales a move to use when faced against Wide Guard.

  • Aurora Veil gives Alolan Ninetales and its teammates damage reduction against both physical and special attacks, improving their staying power.

  • Protect allows Alolan Ninetales to protect itself from attacks like Mega Metagross's Iron Head and Aegislash's Flash Cannon while its teammate takes care of these Pokemon.

  • Icy Wind allows Alolan Ninetales to provide speed control for its team, making it an option if its team struggles to find a place to put speed control.

  • Alolan Ninetales can also make use of Encore to lock foes into status moves like Substitute and Protect and potentially force switches.

  • Alolan Ninetales should run an EV spread of 4 HP / 252 SpA / 252 Spe with a Timid nature, as it needs as much power and speed as it can get. Furthermore, defensive investment is unlikely to prove beneficial, given its subpar bulk sans Aurora Veil.

  • Snow Warning is obligatory, seeing as hail enables the use of Aurora Veil and turns Blizzard into a reliable attack.

  • Focus Sash is the preferred item on Alolan Ninetales, given that it enables it to survive attacks it wouldn't otherwise take, including Kartana's Smart Strike and Mega Metagross's Iron Head.

  • Light Clay extends the duration of Aurora Veil from five turns to eight turns. This may be considered on more defensively oriented and setup-focused teams that can truly reap the benefits of an extended duration of Aurora Veil.

  • As Aurora Veil enhances the bulk of Alolan Ninetales and its teammates, it makes Alolan Ninetales a solid consideration on teams that use setup Pokemon like Snorlax and Calm Mind Tapu Fini or rock-solid defensive Pokemon like Celesteela and Ferrothorn.

  • Given Alolan Ninetales's vulnerability to Steel-type Pokemon like Celesteela and Aegislash, it should be paired with Fire- and Ground-type Pokemon like Landorus-T, Heatran, and Volcarona that can take care of them.

  • Since Mega Charizard Y and Tyranitar are both difficult for Alolan Ninetales, given their ability to completely block Aurora Veil, lower Blizzard's accuracy, and OHKO it altogether, it is a good idea to use Pokemon like Landorus-T and Terrakion with it—the former should be used with Choice Scarf and Rock Slide to even be considered a check to Mega Charizard Y, though.

Marowak-Alola.overview:
• Alolan Marowak, despite being overshadowed by other Fire-types such as Heatran and Incineroar as well as other Lightning Rod users such as Manectric and Raichu, finds its niche in dishing out heavy damage under Trick Room while providing Lightning Rod support.

  • Thick Club combined with decent coverage lets Alolan Marowak use strong attacks on the entire metagame

  • Its Ghost typing allows it to be a pseudo-counter to Gothitelle + Snorlax and Cresselia + Snorlax, the most common Trick Room compositions.

  • Its defensive stats are not terrible, but they result in Alolan Marowak often being knocked out, and it relies on Snarl to survive many special attacks

  • Choice Specs Tapu Fini and Landorus-T can heavily threaten Alolan Marowak with spread moves

  • Although Alolan Marowak is Trick Room reliant to get massive damage off, it is still undersped by notable threats such as Amoonguss, Mega Camerupt, and Snorlax

  • Alolan Marowak lacks item flexibility; without Thick Club, Alolan Marowak's damage becomes laughable, so it is very weak to Knock Off

Offensive Lightning Rod.description:
• Flare Blitz is incredibly powerful, netting KOs on most super effective targets such as Metagross, Celesteela, Ferrothorn, Aegislash, and Amoonguss, even at -1

  • Shadow Bone provides coverage, threatens Cresselia, Tapu Lele, and Gothitelle, and is especially useful against Aegislash because Shadow Bone is a non-contact move, thus avoiding King's Shield Attack drop

  • Low Kick allows Alolan Marowak to knock out Pokemon such as Tyranitar, Heatran, Kangaskhan, and Snorlax that might otherwise wall it

  • Bonemerang nets KOs on Shuca Berry Heatran and also breaks Focus Sash. However, Low Kick is a better option in most cases

  • An EV spread of 236 HP / 28 Atk / 4 Def / 236 SpD with a Sassy nature allows Alolan Marowak to still guarantee KOs on bulky Aegislash, Celesteela, and Metagross with Flare Blitz and survive maximum Attack Landorus-T's Earthquake, maximum Attack Tyranitar's Crunch, fully invested Aegislash's Shadow Ball, and Life Orb Tapu Lele's Psychic under Psychic Terrain. However, after taking these attacks, Alolan Marowak will likely faint due to Flare Blitz recoil or weather damage, so be careful

  • Tapu Fini is almost a requirement for Alolan Marowak, as Misty Terrain prevents Amoonguss from completely neutering Alolan Marowak with Spore. Tapu Fini also threatens Incineroar, Landorus-T, and Scrafty, three of Alolan Marowak's least favorite matchups

  • Alolan Marowak benefits enormously from Trick Room setters such as Cresselia and Porygon2, as they cover weaknesses to Landorus-T and allow Alolan Marowak to take advantage of its low Speed stat. Porygon2 can also Ally Switch Ghost moves and Z-Moves away from Alolan Marowak

  • Bulkier Alolan Marowak sets especially love partnering with Landorus deterrents such as Porygon2 and Milotic, as much of their Attack investment has been traded for added bulk

  • It is generally not a good idea to lead with Alolan Marowak, as having it hidden away from opponents provides extra pressure and dissuades them from using Electric-type attacks

  • In general, Alolan Marowak should always be the third or fourth Pokemon you select, switching in only to redirect Electric moves, receive hefty Snorlax Returns, or resist Fairy, Ice, and Fire attacks. However, against Trick Room teams, Alolan Marowak can be led immediately to put pressure on Trick Room setters and sweepers from turn one.

  • Because of Alolan Marowak's immunity to both Electric and Normal, as well as resisting Fairy and Fire, you can switch it safely into common Pokemon such as Tapu Koko, Snorlax, Heatran, and Mega Charizard Y

  • Take note that Mega Charizard Y still does hefty damage with sun-boosted Fire-type moves, especially if you are not running bulky Alolan Marowak

  • Against the popular pairing of Zapdos and Landorus-T, it is generally not a good idea to switch Alolan Marowak in, as the opponent can freely click Earthquake. However, if you are setting up Trick Room on the same turn, Alolan Marowak can tank the Earthquake and begin pressuring both Landorus-T and Zapdos the following turn or sweeping.

  • Alolan Marowak also matches up poorly against sand teams; however, with Trick Room up, Alolan Marowak can easily KO Tyranitar and Excadrill with Low Kick.

All-out Attacker.description: This set intends to maximize the benefit of Parental Bond in becoming as immediately threatening as possible. Consequently, a spread of 252 Atk / 252 Spe and using Double-Edge is the most common approach, although utilising a bulkier spread with Frustration is an option. For example, 164 HP / 228 Atk / 116 Spe outspeeds positive-natured base 70s and ensures Low Kick OHKOes foes such as Heatran and Hydreigon. This can be taken further with 228 HP / 228 Atk / 28 Def / 4 SpD / 20 Spe, which outpaces neutral base 70s and survives attacks such as Landorus-T’s Tectonic Rage and Choice Specs Hydreigon’s Draco Meteor.

Snorlax.overview:
• With a low base Speed of 30 that makes it one of the slowest Pokemon in VGC, Snorlax functions very well under Trick Room both as a Trick Room sweeper and against opposing Trick Room teams. It notably Speed ties with Amoonguss.

  • With base defenses of 160 / 65 / 110 and the combination of Gluttony, Wiki Berry, and Recycle, it is very bulky and often requires a lot of effort to KO. Though its lower Defense can be exploited, it can be mitigated somewhat by supporting Snorlax with an Intimidate user like Landorus-T or Incineroar.

  • Snorlax can either threaten OHKOs on most of the metagame after a single Belly Drum or opt for a slower boosting but harder to take down set utilizing Curse, often letting Snorlax function as a team's wincon.

  • Many teams have moves that prevent setup sweepers (including Snorlax) from setting up, such as Taunt, Haze, Roar, and Clear Smog, or Knock Off, which removes Snorlax's Berry and renders Recycle useless. Due to this, and its low Speed, Snorlax often needs support such as Trick Room, Fake Out and/or redirection moves to truly shine.

  • Snorlax is reliant on a coverage move such as High Horsepower or Fire Punch to break through specific Pokemon, most notably Ghost-type Pokemon such as Aegislash. The choice of coverage move (or lack thereof) can lead it to being checked by certain Pokemon, such as Kartana and Drifblim without Fire Punch and Tyranitar and Heatran without High Horsepower.

DrumLax.description:
• Belly Drum lets Snorlax OHKO most of the metagame after a boost. Return is the basic STAB move that Snorlax will be attacking with a majority of the time. High Horsepower and Fire Punch hit the Ghost-types that it otherwise wouldn't be able to touch like Mega Gengar and Aegislash and OHKO many Pokemon that resist its Normal STAB attacks at +6 like Mega Metagross. After Belly Drum, High Horsepower OHKOes Tyranitar and even Shuca Berry Heatran, whilst Fire Punch OHKOes Drifblim, non-Focus Sash Kartana, Celesteela, and Ferrothorn. High Horsepower is generally preferred over Fire Punch, as it has better neutral coverage alongside Return.

  • Protect is a strong option to allow Snorlax to stall while a teammate either sets Trick Room or sets up board position or for protection against a predicted Z-Move. Typically Protect should not be dropped in most cases unless you have redirection and Fake Out support to help set up Snorlax. Recycle, bringing back Wiki Berry, effectively functions as a 50% HP recovery move and can be used to take advantage of opposing passive play or when both the opposing Pokemon do little to threaten Snorlax.

  • The combination of Wiki Berry and Gluttony enables Snorlax to immediately regain the 50% HP lost from using Belly Drum, preserving its bulk. Wiki Berry is chosen over other 50%-healing Berries to confuse potential Adamant Bug Bite users like Mega Scizor.

  • The EVs and nature focus on Snorlax's weaker physical bulk whilst providing an even HP number so that Wiki Berry activates after using Belly Drum and ensuring that Tapu Lele's Shattered Psyche cannot OHKO Snorlax in Psychic Terrain. Even with only 4 Attack EVs, Snorlax will OHKO all but the bulkiest of Pokemon and those that resist its STAB attacks—in fact, 252 HP / 4 Def Cresselia has a 62.5% chance to be OHKOed by Return! Minimum Speed makes Snorlax faster under Trick Room.

  • Snorlax can switch in either on weak hits or after a KO, or it can be used as a lead. It should only use Belly Drum if the user feels confident it can then sweep the opposing team (usually mid- or late-game); otherwise, it is safer to either deal chip damage to the opponent with its attacking moves or switch it out and attempt to sweep later.

  • Strong teammates including Trick Room setters such as Cresselia, Gothitelle, and Mimikyu for speed control, Intimidate users such as Landorus-T, Incineroar, and Mega Manectric to mitigate its weaker Defense stat, Fake Out or redirection users such as Incineroar, Amoonguss, and Clefairy to help set up, and Tapu Fini to provide status protection through Misty Terrain.

CurseLax.description:
• Curse Snorlax requires less support from the rest of the team than DrumLax, as it does not sacrifice its HP to boost its Attack and also boosts its Defense in the process. However, it is more susceptible to opposing Pokemon's Intimidate lowering its Attack stat and may need multiple boosts before it has sufficient Attack to sweep your opponent. This set trades power for not having to be as committed to setting up as Belly Drum Snorlax.

  • Double-Edge is preferred over Return for the higher damage. With Curse boosting Defense without cutting Snorlax's HP, the recoil isn't as harmful as on a DrumLax set. Return is still viable as a non-recoil STAB attack, however. High Horsepower and Fire Punch both offer useful coverage against Pokemon that resist or are immune to Snorlax's STAB move. High Horsepower is generally preferred over Fire Punch, as it deals more damage against targets weak to both moves like Mega Metagross. High Horsepower is better against Mega Gengar, Tyranitar, and Heatran, whilst Fire Punch is better against Kartana, Celesteela, and Drifblim. Recycle takes advantage of the Defense boosts and helps Snorlax set up multiple Curses.

  • The EVs give Double-Edge a near-guaranteed 2HKO on 236 HP / 116 Def Zapdos without a Curse boost and then maximize its weaker Defense stat. Curselax does not need to run as much Defense investment as DrumLax because of Curse enabling more Attack investment. Minimum Speed is preferred to make Snorlax as slow as possible under Trick Room.

  • Gluttony and Wiki Berry enable an automatic 50% HP recovery when Snorlax loses half its HP, which can be reactivated with Recycle.

  • Snorlax should attempt to sweep mid- to late-game when its threats have been weakened or removed, coming in either after a free switch or on a weak attack like Cresselia's Ice Beam. Afterwards it should usually set up Curse once or twice to boost its stats before attempting to sweep, using Recycle as needed after Wiki Berry has been used to bring it back.

  • This Snorlax requires less team support than Belly Drum Snorlax. However, it still benefits from Trick Room setters such as Cresselia and Gothitelle, and Tapu Fini, which protects Snorlax from status with Misty Terrain, in particular burn and poison. Incineroar threatens Kartana, which can bypass Snorlax's Curse boosts with Sacred Sword, and can switch into Tapu Lele's Shattered Psyche (which in Psychic Terrain threatens an OHKO on Snorlax), whilst providing Fake Out and Intimidate support to help Snorlax set up.

Zapdos.overview:
• Thanks to its above-average bulk and decent Speed, Zapdos is one of the best Tailwind setters in VGC.

  • Zapdos's typing is pretty good defensively, leaving it with some good resistances and immunity to Ground-type attacks. Unfortunately, Zapdos has a weakness to the very common Rock Slide.

  • It can survive strong neutral attacks such as Mega Kangaskhan's Double-Edge, super effective hits such as Mega Tyranitar's Rock Slide, and even some Z-Moves like Incineroar's Malicious Moonsault, but it is unable to take on any stronger attacks.

  • Pressure allows Zapdos to leech PP from low-PP moves such as Tapu Bulu's Stone Edge.

  • On the offensive side, Zapdos faces competition from faster and stronger Pokemon like Thundurus-T, Mega Manectric, and Tapu Koko. Zapdos sets itself apart from them with its bulk, and, unlike Mega Manectric, Zapdos doesn't use a Mega slot.

Offensive Tailwind.description:
• Tailwind doubles your team's Speed for three turns. It helps Pokemon with mediocre Speed outspeed faster foes.

  • Thunderbolt is the STAB move, hitting Water- and Flying-types such as Politoed and Celesteela.

  • Hidden Power Ice hits Landorus-T and Mega Salamence hard.

  • Detect allows Zapdos to survive strong attacks and double targets. Heat Wave is a spread move that hits Grass-types, especially Ferrothorn, hard.

  • Electrium Z is necessary for the powerful 175-Base Power Gigavolt Havoc, which has a big chance to OHKO +1 Tapu Fini with some chip damage.

  • The given EV spread with Modest nature gives Zapdos much offensive presence. With this spread, Zapdos OHKOes uninvested Landorus-T and usually OHKOes Naive Mega Salamence with Hidden Power Ice, while it survives Jolly Mega Metagross's Zen Headbutt under Psychic Terrain and Timid Mega Charizard Y's sun-boosted Flamethrower. A Timid nature with 4 Def / 252 SpA / 252 Spe also can be used, as it Speed ties with other positive-nature base 100s like Mega Charizard Y and 2HKOes no-bulk Mega Metagross with Heat Wave, though with this EV spread Zapdos loses a lot of bulk.

  • You should use Zapdos either early- or mid-game to provide speed control for your team. Leading with Zapdos is fine because it brings Zapdos onto the field safely.

  • Don't overrate Zapdos's bulk; switch it out from possible super effective moves or Z-Moves. Alternatively, use Detect.

  • Zapdos appreciates Wide Guard support because it is weak to the multi-target Rock Slide. Aegislash is decent teammate because it can provide Wide Guard support and switch into Rock-type attacks. In return, Zapdos can freely switch into Ground-type attacks.

  • Fake Out support from the likes of Incineroar and Scrafty helps Zapdos to setup Tailwind more easily.

  • Steel-types such as Mega Metagross and Kartana work with Zapdos well because they threaten Tyranitar, one of the best Zapdos counters. Zapdos can take on Water-types such as Tapu Fini and switch into Ground-type attacks. These Pokemon also appreciate the speed control provided by Tailwind.

Terrain Abuser.description:
• Tailwind provides speed control for your team for three turns.

  • Thunderbolt hits Flying- and Water-types like Celesteela and Tapu Fini.

  • Hidden Power Ice with Thunderbolt provides good coverage. It hits Mega Salamence and Landorus-T for a large amount of damage. Heat Wave is a spread move that hits Grass-types such as Amoonguss harder than Hidden Power Ice.

  • Roost increases Zapdos's longevity and allows it to stay on the field for more time.

  • Misty Seed and Psychic Seed increase Zapdos's special bulk by one stage in Misty and Psychic Terrain, respectively.

  • The given EV spread with the Modest nature allows Zapdos to survive Tapu Lele's Shattered Psyche in Psychic Terrain when Zapdos's Seed is activated and outpace +1 base 100s under Tailwind. Also, Zapdos 2HKOes most standard variants of Tapu Fini with Thunderbolt.

  • You must be careful with switches because Terrain Seeds are consumed after activating, and without a Special Defense boost, Zapdos loses a lot of special bulk. Before bringing Zapdos into the field with the Terrain that activates its Seed, you should eliminate or weaken Pokemon that can force it out.

  • You must have Tapu Lele or Tapu Fini in your team, depending on Zapdos's Seed.

  • Steel-types such as Kartana and Mega Metagross can take on Pokemon that are very threatening to Zapdos such as Tyranitar, while Zapdos freely switches into Ground-type attacks for them. Mega Metagross is particularly useful if you run Psychic Seed Zapdos, as Psychic Terrain will strengthen Mega Metagross's Zen Headbutt alongside with activating Zapdos's Psychic Seed.

  • Intimidate support from the likes of Incineroar, Scrafty, and Landorus-T helps Zapdos to take on physical attacks more easily. Scrafty deserves a special mention because it provides both Fake Out and Intimidate support and threatens Tyranitar.

Bulky Tailwind.description:
• Tailwind helps Zapdos's teammates to outspeed many foes for three turns.

  • Thunderbolt is the strongest of Zapdos's attacks and hits Water- and Flying-types.

  • Hidden Power Ice gives Zapdos coverage for Landorus-T and Mega Salamence, while the multi-target Heat Wave helps Zapdos to knock out Grass- and Steel-types like Mega Metagross and Ferrothorn.

  • Roost heals half of Zapdos's HP, increasing its longevity. Detect helps to reveal opposing Pokemon's moves and allows Zapdos to survive double targeting.

  • Wiki Berry and Sitrus Berry heal 50% or 25% when Zapdos is at 25% or 50%, respectively. Wiki Berry is generally more useful because it restores more HP, but Sitrus Berry is less risky.

  • The given EV spread with a Calm nature enables Zapdos to be 3HKOed by Adamant Landorus-T's Rock Slide, survive Ludicolo's rain-boosted Hydro Vortex 15 out of 16 times, and outspeed +1 base 100s under Tailwind. Alternatively, a Modest nature can be used for more power in exchange for special bulk.

  • This Zapdos set is good for teams that don't wish to rely on a Seed or that don't have place for Tapu Fini or Tapu Lele.

  • Steel-types are good teammates. Aegislash and Celesteela provide additional utility in Wide Guard, which protects Zapdos from Rock Slide and other multi-target moves.

  • Intimidate and Fake Out support from the likes of Incineroar, Scrafty, and Hitmontop is appreciated by Zapdos, as it helps Zapdos to survive more physical attacks and set up Tailwind.

  • Tyranitar can be a good teammate for Zapdos because they cover each other's weaknesses pretty well.

Belly Drum.description: Azumarill is the only viable Pokemon in the format with access to Belly Drum and a priority attack, making it a great setup sweeper. Sitrus Berry and HP EVs that grant an even number of HP are used so that Azumarill can remain healthy after Belly Drum’s use. The 4 Defense EVs ensure Azumarill survives Mega Salamence’s Double-Edge. Fake Out Mega Kangaskhan makes an excellent partner, as it can immobilize a foe hindersome to Azumarill’s setup such as a Taunt user. Redirection support from the likes of Rage Powder Amoonguss, which resists Electric, and Follow Me Togekiss, which can redirect the moves of Grass-types, can also keep Azumarill unharmed.

Assault Vest.description: Azumarill’s natural bulk combined with Assault Vest makes it a good switch-in to common special attackers. The aforementioned means this set should avoid the lead position, where it’s unavailable to switch in and vulnerable to Intimidate. The given EVs importantly allow Azumarill to survive Adamant Mega Salamence’s Double-Edge. This set is commonly utilized on sand teams featuring Tyranitar and Mega Salamence, as Azumarill can easily switch into the Water- and Ice-type attacks aimed at them. The same goes for Landorus-T, whose Intimidate combined with Salamence’s access to the same ability compensates for Azumarill’s lower Defense.

Kingdra.overview:
• Kingdra is one of the best rain sweepers available thanks to its good offensive typing and access to spread Muddy Water, both of which also help to distinguish itself from Ludicolo.

  • Kingdra's solid Water / Dragon typing also leaves it with few weaknesses, though its mediocre bulk makes it vulnerable to strong neutral hits.

  • Ordinarily uncommon support options, such as Disable and Quash, give Kingdra the flexibility to support its team when necessary.

  • Kingdra's STAB moves are resisted by common threats, most notably Tapu Fini and Ferrothorn.

  • Kingdra is highly reliant on rain due to its middling Speed and lackluster damage output outside of rain, which causes a loss of momentum if the opponent activates other weather or gains a Speed advantage from Tailwind or Trick Room.

Rain Sweeper.description:
• Muddy Water is a powerful STAB spread move under rain that also has a decent chance to lower the accuracy of its targets. Generally, this move will be spammed until a foe is put into KO range of another move.

  • Draco Meteor serves as a secondary STAB move to hit Water-resistant foes and beat Dragon-types, such as opposing Kingdra and Mega Salamence.

  • Ice Beam can be used to KO Dragon- and Grass-types without worrying about Misty Terrain or the Special Attack drop from Draco Meteor, although running this leaves Kingdra walled by bulky Water-types.

  • Hydro Pump is valuable as a strong single-target STAB attack, finishing off targets that Muddy Water can't KO and letting Kingdra bypass Wide Guard Celesteela and Aegislash, which otherwise wall it.

  • Rain Dance allows Kingdra to set up independently, improving momentum by making it unnecessary to switch your weather setter in and out to maintain field presence.

  • Protect can be used to shield Kingdra while its partner removes a threat, punishes double targets, and scouts a foe’s actions.

  • The given EV spread and nature allow Kingdra to hit as hard and as fast as possible, with the four Special Defense EVs ensuring Download users like Porygon2 don't receive a Special Attack boost.

  • Waterium Z enables the use of Hydro Vortex, which is notable in providing a perfectly accurate Water-type move as much as in providing a strong one. Alternatively, Life Orb gives Kingdra a more consistent damage boost.

  • If your opponent doesn't have weather setters, such as Tyranitar and Mega Charizard Y, Kingdra makes a perfect lead to punch holes early in the opposing team. If they have a setter, consider removing it before sending out Kingdra.

  • Partners with the Drizzle ability are required to activate Swift Swim. Pelipper grants Tailwind and the ability to hit Grass-types, while Politoed offers Helping Hand support and more bulk.

  • Since Kingdra relies heavily on its Speed advantage, running Taunt on at least one teammate to stop Tailwind and Trick Room is recommended.

  • Running Pokemon with strong Fire- and Electric-type moves, such as Incineroar and Tapu Koko, respectively, is encouraged to avoid Ferrothorn and Celesteela late-game, as they largely wall Kingdra's attacks.

  • Mega Gengar is a good teammate, as it's able to use Shadow Tag to trap and remove Grass-types, bulky Water-types, and opposing weather setters, making it easier for Kingdra to sweep.

Suicune.overview:
• Suicune serves as an excellent bulky support Pokemon that is capable of providing a reliable form of speed control consistently.

  • Its solid bulk and only two weaknesses allow Suicune to tank a wide range of attacks and make it an excellent switch-in to Heatran, Volcarona, Tapu Fini, rain teams, and sand teams.

  • Suicune further sets itself apart from other bulky Water-types by possessing valuable support options such as Snarl, Tailwind, and Roar. Combined with its excellent bulk, it can apply these moves consistently throughout the battle.

  • The abundance of Z-Moves and Tapu Koko makes using Suicune harder, as there are now much easier ways to KO it, and as such, they need to be played around carefully.

  • Tapu Fini and Milotic give Suicune competition in the bulky Water-type role, as they possess somewhat similar levels of bulk and have far more useful abilities.

Offensive Support.description:
• Tailwind is the speed control of choice, as it doubles your entire team's Speed and helps outspeed threats like Choice Scarf Landorus-T, Mega Metagross, and Quiver Dance Volcarona after a boost.

  • Scald serves as Suicune's primary STAB move, dealing sufficient damage to the likes of Heatran, Tyranitar, Excadrill, and Incineroar and having a 30% chance to burn the opposing Pokemon, effectively crippling physical attackers.

  • Ice Beam guarantees OHKO on Mega Salamence and non-Assault Vest Landorus-T, both of which are popular Pokemon in VGC 2018.

  • As an additional form of speed control, Icy Wind can be used over Ice Beam on bulkier variants, but it lacks offensive pressure.

  • Snarl helps weaken your opponent's special attackers and increases your team's longevity. Combined with an Intimidate user, it helps weaken both your opponent's physically and specially offensive capabilities. As an alternative, Protect can be used over Snarl to scout for incoming Z-Moves and stall out Trick Room or your opponent's Tailwind.

  • Mago Berry is Suicune's item of choice, as it greatly helps with longevity, healing 50% of its HP.

  • A Calm Nature with 252 HP and 20 Special Defense EVs gives Suicune a great deal of special bulk and allows it to tank Z-Moves like Tapu Lele's Shattered Psyche and Heatran's Bloom Doom after a Snarl, and it can also survive boosted special attacks like Tapu Fini's Moonblast and Volcarona's Giga Drain.

  • 212 Special Attack EVs allow Suicune to always OHKO uninvested Mega Salamence with Ice Beam and 2HKO Heatran with Scald.

  • 252 HP and 4 Defense EVs allow Suicune to survive 252 Attack Jolly Kartana's Leaf Blade and gives Suicune more overall bulk when combined with a Mago Berry.

  • 20 Speed EVs allow Suicune to outspeed Adamant Choice Scarf Landorus-T in Tailwind, and the remaining EVs were dumped into Special Defense for general bulk.

  • Mega Kangaskhan is an excellent teammate, as it helps Suicune set up Tailwind thanks to its Fake Out support and takes out opposing Tapu Koko with Parental Bond-boosted Double-Edge.

  • Mega Salamence goes well with Suicune, as it helps take down Grass-type Pokemon, which otherwise threatens Suicune, and provides Intimidate support prior to its Mega Evolution.

  • Incineroar has great synergy with Suicune, providing Fake Out support so Suicune can set up Tailwind safely, serving as a Grass-type check, and having access to Intimidate to weaken any physical attackers.

  • Tapu Bulu is an efficient Terrain setter that goes well with Suicune, OHKOing Tapu Koko and bulky Water-type Pokemon like Tapu Fini with its Terrain-boosted Grass-type attacks, while also providing recovery with Grassy Terrain.

  • Landorus-T serves as an amazing switch-in to Electric-type attacks meant for Suicune, thus giving your team great momentum.

  • Offensive Pokemon like Tapu Lele, Volcarona, and Heatran appreciate speed control and thus make good teammates for Suicune.

  • While Mago Berry might be the most used item on Suicune, other sets with Psychic Seed or Grassy Seed can be used with Tapu Lele and Tapu Bulu, respectively.

  • Roar can be considered over Snarl to phaze bulky setup sweepers like Snorlax, Azumarill, and Tapu Fini.

  • Alternatively, Mirror Coat can be used to OHKO bulky special attackers with ease after tanking one of their moves. This works especially well against Soundproof Kommo-o, which is unaffected by Snarl and Roar.

Choice Scarf.description: Choice Scarf is the most common choice of item for Tyranitar, as it lessens dependence on speed control from partners. A Jolly nature is used, as it’s needed to outrun positive-natured base 110s. Typically this set will be selecting Rock Slide as a result of its STAB spread damage and 51% chance to make at least one foe flinch; deviation will occur only against specific threats such as Wide Guard Aegislash, Landorus-T, and opposing Tyranitar. This set is a component of a popular sand core featuring Sand Rush Excadrill and Mega Salamence, known for its ability to deal massive amounts of spread damage before the foe can move.

Trick Room Attacker.description: When paired with a Trick Room user such as Mega Gardevoir or Cresselia, Tyranitar’s low Speed can be alleviated without sacrificing its bulk and item slot. The items presented are roughly equivalent in viability, so pick whichever you’d prefer. Darkinium Z provides more immediate damage, notably having a chance to OHKO even the bulkiest Cresselia. Weakness Policy is easily activated with Tyranitar’s myriad of weaknesses but excellent bulk, and it allows Tyranitar to deal massive spread damage at +2 Attack with Rock Slide. Rage Powder Amoonguss is a good partner for redirecting Fighting-type moves away.

Dragon Dance.description: Mega Tyranitar’s increased bulk and speed allow it to more effectively pull off a Dragon Dance set. A Jolly nature and maximum Speed EVs are typically non-negotiable, as they allow Mega Tyranitar to outpace prominent foes such as Mega Salamence and Mega Gengar after a Dragon Dance. The remaining EVs are commonly invested in Attack, although a spread of 252 HP / 4 Atk / 252 Spe can be adopted for more bulk. Rage Powder Amoonguss makes for an excellent partner, as it can help with setup, notably redirecting and resisting Fighting-type moves. Likewise, Sand Rush Excadrill gains Speed from sand and eliminates Fairy-types.

Mega Physical Attacker.description: Generally speaking, Blaziken should not be a team’s first choice of Mega Evolution; however, since Mega Blaziken possesses a physical damage output comparable to Life Orb Blaziken with a 20-point increase in base Speed, it does still have a niche. Low Kick is typically the superior Fighting-type STAB move, as it has a high Base Power against common targets such as Mega Kangaskhan and Heatran and doesn’t drop Attack. However, Superpower is more effective against light foes such as Politoed and Ludicolo. Utilizing support partners like Rage Powder Amoonguss and Storm Drain Gastrodon is essential to preserving Mega Blaziken’s health.

Mixed Attacker.description: Fire and Fighting having great super effective coverage together, and Speed Boost allowing Blaziken to outpace the majority of the unboosted metagame, makes Blaziken a good check to many common threats. The given EVs allow Superpower to OHKO 4 HP Mega Kangaskhan and Hidden Power Ice to OHKO Mega Salamence while letting Blaziken outspeed Landorus-T. These are good examples of Pokemon mixed Blaziken is able to check for partners such as Hydreigon. Accompanying Blaziken with Water-type checks such as Tapu Koko and Amoonguss is also a good idea, as Blaziken struggles against these.

Swampertite.description: Mega Swampert’s high Attack gives it a niche over other Swim Swim users such as Ludicolo and Kingdra. Ice Punch is typically the best coverage move for Water-resistant Dragon- and Grass-types such as Salamence and Amoonguss, although Superpower hits Mega Kangaskhan and Ferrothorn and Rock Slide OHKOes Mega Charizard Y as it attempts to reset sun. Damp is chosen over the useless Torrent in case Explosion is used as Swampert switches in. The EVs and nature let Mega Swampert outpace Choice Scarf Landorus-T in rain while maximizing Attack. Drizzle Pelipper is often the preferred ally over Politoed due to its Ground immunity.

Ludicolo.overview:
• Ludicolo is the premier rain sweeper of VGC 2018, having just enough Speed and Special Attack to become a potent threat under gloomy skies.

  • It also has above average coverage for a Water-type, being among the few to hit Tapu Fini hard thanks to its Grass-type STAB.

  • Fake Out is an excellent selling point as well, since under the rain, few Pokemon can offer a faster flinch than Ludicolo.

  • It even has a good Special Defense stat, which makes Ludicolo trickier for special attackers to KO than expected.

  • However, Ludicolo has a poor Defense stat, which lets bulky physical attackers revenge kill it easily.

  • Ludicolo is highly reliant on rain to function. Without rain support, it's hard to justify it over bulkier offensive Water-types such as Tapu Fini.

Rain Sweeper.description:
• Hydro Pump is extremely powerful in the rain, especially when used with Waterium Z. Hydro Vortex coming from Ludicolo in the rain is capable of OHKOing bulky offensive threats such as Mega Kangaskhan and Mega Metagross.

  • Although it doesn't take advantage of Waterium Z nearly as well, Scald is a more reliable option than Hydro Pump overall, and its burn chance can come in handy, especially when carrying Assault Vest.

  • Ice Beam gives Ludicolo a way to OHKO Mega Salamence, Garchomp, and non-Assault Vest Landorus-T regardless of the weather, in addition to hitting Naganadel and Hydreigon hard. It's also Ludicolo's only way of dealing reasonable damage to Grass-types such as Tapu Bulu and Amoonguss.

  • Energy Ball is Ludicolo's most consistently powerful Grass-type STAB attack, notably 2HKOing maximum HP Tapu Fini. However, Giga Drain is a reasonable alternative for the healing it gives Ludicolo, at the cost of power.

  • Fake Out is an incredible option for causing foes to flinch on Ludicolo's first turn out as long as Psychic Terrain isn't up. However, Protect is a reasonable alternative for dodging powerful attacks.

  • Waterium Z gives Ludicolo a one-time chance to drown most Pokemon that don't resist Water-type attacks, especially if using Hydro Pump.

  • Assault Vest takes advantage of Ludicolo's good Special Defense stat, letting it survive surprising attacks. If using Assault Vest, a bulkier spread of 92 HP / 4 Def / 124 SpA / 124 SpD / 164 Spe can be considered. This spread still has enough Special Attack to OHKO Mega Salamence with Ice Beam, and it can survive some powerful attacks, such as Kartana's Leaf Blade, Tapu Lele's Shattered Psyche, and Jolly Mega Kangaskhan's Double-Edge.

  • Another EV spread to consider for Assault Vest Ludicolo is 204 HP / 20 Def / 124 SpA / 76 SpD / 84 Spe. This still allows Ludicolo to outspeed base 130 Speed Pokemon in the rain such as Tapu Koko and Mega Gengar, in exchange for much more bulk. For example, Life Orb Tapu Koko will fail to 2HKO this Ludicolo with Thunderbolt, and it even survives Modest Tapu Lele's Shattered Psyche.

  • Life Orb gives Ludicolo a consistent power boost at the cost of its health. Most notably, this lets Ice Beam OHKO Naganadel and fast Assault Vest Landorus-T and lets Scald OHKO Nihilego in the rain. However, the recoil makes Ludicolo easy to wear down.

  • Swift Swim and a Modest nature are required for Ludicolo to blast through most Pokemon. Maximum Special Attack and Speed investment is fine if using Waterium Z or Life Orb to maximize damage output.

  • A Timid nature can be used to outspeed Jolly Choice Scarf Kartana, Modest Choice Scarf Naganadel, and Timid Choice Scarf Blacephalon, but this does result in a significant power loss.

  • Since Ludicolo is a rain sweeper, rain setters are required teammates. Pelipper is a great choice, since it hits Amoonguss and Tapu Bulu hard and is able to set up Tailwind to deal with fast Choice Scarf users.

  • Politoed is a reasonable option due to its support movepool and its ability to viably use a Choice Scarf. Politoed can also run Focus Blast and Fightinium Z to deal severe damage to Ferrothorn, a common problem for rain teams.

  • Putting Rain Dance on Pokemon such as Gothitelle or Cresselia can be an effective way to surprise opposing weather setters, though it should be a backup option rather than the main way of setting up rain.

  • Ludicolo teams will need a way to deal with Mega Charizard Y and, to a lesser extent, Torkoal, since sun cripples Ludicolo's offensive capabilities. Preparing for Tyranitar and Alolan Ninetales can be a good idea too.

  • Ludicolo especially hates Trick Room due to its reliance on Swift Swim. Taunt users such as Tapu Koko and Tapu Lele can be useful, or even having a Trick Room user of your own such as Cresselia can help for resetting Trick Room.

  • Prepare for bulky Grass-types such as Ferrothorn, Tapu Bulu, and Amoonguss, since they are able to survive Ludicolo's assaults with little issue and hit it hard. Ferrothorn is especially troubling, since it isn't weak to Pelipper's Hurricane.

Drizzle.description: Pelipper and Politoed are the only two users of Drizzle in the format and, given that the former is more offensive, it typically sees the most use. A Ground immunity and access to STAB Hurricane and Tailwind are the main contributing factors. Scald is often the better Water-type STAB move given its accuracy and chance to burn, although Brine takes advantage of Pelipper’s low Speed in dealing massive damage to a foe already harmed by its partner. Swift Swim users such as Ludicolo and Mega Swampert are obvious beneficiaries of rain. Steel-types such as Metagross and Ferrothorn appreciate it weakening Fire-type moves.

Breloom.overview:
• Breloom's viability has sharply decreased since VGC 2015.

  • Electric and Misty Terrain both block Spore, and Breloom is arguably outclassed by Tapu Bulu and Kartana as a Grass-type physical attacker.

  • Technician is still a fantastic ability on Breloom, powering up many of its main attacking moves such as Bullet Seed, Mach Punch, and Rock Tomb.

  • Breloom still has a niche as the fastest Spore user outside of Smeargle, and the only Pokemon that can both put enemies to sleep and hit hard.

  • Breloom requires both Tailwind from its team and denial of opposing speed control to fully function.

Offensive Spore.description:
• Spore is the main reason to use Breloom over Tapu Bulu or Kartana.

  • Mach Punch is a powerful priority move, boosted by STAB and Technician.

  • Bullet Seed is Breloom's main attacking move, dealing good damage as well as breaking Focus Sash and Sturdy.

  • Protect takes advantage of Breloom's tendency to be double targeted and can potentially allow for a free Tailwind.

  • Jolly is the preferred nature because many Pokemon are EVed specifically to outspeed neutral-natured base 70s, but Adamant can be used if you are confident with speed control.

  • Breloom works best as a lead paired with a Tailwind setter, since its threat of Spore forces the opponent to respect it. Ideally, Breloom should take advantage of its Speed to use Spore on as many things as possible so that its teammates can sweep.

  • Breloom also functions well as part of a Fire/Water/Grass core - for example, with Suicune and Heatran.

  • Tapu Lele is another great partner for Breloom because Psychic Terrain protects Breloom from priority, especially Fake Out, and overrides the Spore-blocking Electric and Misty Terrains. However, be aware that Psychic Terrain will also prevent Breloom from using Mach Punch against grounded enemies.

Choice Scarf.description:
• A Jolly nature paired with a Choice Scarf allows Breloom to reach 201 Speed, outspeeding maximum Speed base 130 Pokemon such as Tapu Koko.

  • Spore quickly puts a foe to sleep to allow for Breloom's partner to attack or set up.

  • Superpower is Breloom's most consistent move and can OHKO 4 HP / 0 Def Mega Kangaskhan.

  • Rock Tomb is mainly used to OHKO Charizard and Volcarona, along with damaging other Flying-types.

  • Ideally, Breloom should be used as a lead so that it can quickly use Spore and grab momentum for its team. Choice Scarf Breloom is best used alongside Pokemon that set up to sweep, such as Quiver Dance Volcarona and Dragon Dance Mega Tyranitar.

  • Tapu Lele is a fantastic partner as well due to its ability to block Fake Out.

All-out Attacker.description: Mega Mawile's Huge Power grants it the highest Attack stat in the game, only not being used immediately when Intimidate will be useful later. Steel / Fairy typing is a boon defensively, as its two weaknesses can be mitigated by partners such as Drizzle Politoed or Pelipper and Tapu Bulu. Consequently, Mega Mawile is often found on semi-Trick Room teams with the aforementioned Pokemon alongside Swift Swim Kingdra or Ludicolo and Trick Room Cresselia or Gothitelle, which, respectively, take advantage of rain and compensate for Mawile's low Speed. Utilize Rock Slide over Play Rough if Fire-types like Charizard and Volcarona are problematic.

Camerupt.overview:
• With one of the lowest Speed stats at base 20, Mega Camerupt can play in Trick Room teams very well.

  • Its decent bulk allows Mega Camerupt to take on some strong neutral attacks such as Mega Kangaskhan's Double-Edge and Mega Salamence's Draco Meteor.

  • Mega Camerupt's high Special Attack and ability Sheer Force allow it to hit for large amounts of damage. Mega Camerupt can OHKO Mega Metagross and 2HKO Tapu Lele.

  • Mega Camerupt is checked by the very common Tapu Fini due to its 4x weakness to Water-type attacks and Tapu Fini's good special bulk. Mega Camerupt is also threatened by Landorus-T, which can OHKO it with Earthquake.

  • Mega Camerupt faces competition from Heatran even on full Trick Room teams and from Mega Charizard Y on semi-Trick Room teams, as they are also Fire-types that can spam Heat Wave. The former is particularly notable due to it not using a Mega slot.

Trick Room Attacker.description:
• Heat Wave is a good STAB spread move that hits Grass- and Steel-types such as Tapu Bulu, Kartana, and Celesteela, which has an immunity to Earth Power, hard. Heat Wave also gets a power boost from Sheer Force. Eruption does slightly more damage than Heat Wave, has higher accuracy, and has synergy with Grassy Terrain recovery, but Heat Wave is more consistent because Eruption's damage depends on Mega Camerupt's HP. Mega Camerupt is able to threaten the Grass-types that resist Ground with its STAB Fire-type moves.

  • Earth Power is a single target move that can hit Steel- and Rock-types such as Aegislash, particularly if it runs Wide Guard, and Tyranitar for heavy damage.

  • Nature Power in Grassy Terrain transforms into Energy Ball, which is a good answer for opposing Water-types. Flamethrower is a single target move that can hit Wide Guard Celesteela. It's also useful as a backup move if Mega Camerupt is using Eruption and is low on HP. Fire Blast OHKOes specially defensive Amoonguss and Celesteela, but its bad accuracy makes it less consistent than Flamethrower.

  • Protect is a very important move. It allows Mega Camerupt to protect itself from double targeting and gives it a free turn for a teammate.

  • Solid Rock is the pre-Mega ability of choice because it reduces damage from super effective attacks and allows Camerupt to switch into attacks more freely.

  • The given EV spread with a Quiet nature and 0 Speed IVs maximizes Mega Camerupt's damage output and minimizes its Speed, which is important for successful use under Trick Room.

  • Mega Camerupt is good mid-game when Trick Room is set up and threats are weakened or eliminated. Mega Camerupt can also be used early-game to punch holes in the opposing team, but Trick Room must be set up.

  • For successful use, Mega Camerupt requires Trick Room, so a Trick Room setter such as Porygon2, Gothitelle, or Oranguru is necessary in tandem with Mega Camerupt. Oranguru works especially well because with Instruct, it can provide Mega Camerupt with two attacks instead of one.

  • Tapu Bulu is an excellent teammate because it sets up Grassy Terrain, which turns Nature Power into Energy Ball and weakens Earthquake. Tapu Bulu is useful outside of Trick Room if you failed to set it up. In return, Mega Camerupt can take on Poison-type attacks and threatens Steel-types.

  • Ferrothorn is also a good teammate. It can take on Water-types such as Tapu Fini, switch into Ground-type attacks, and function under Trick Room. In return, Mega Camerupt can freely switch into a Fire-type attack.

Mixed Attacker.description: High attacking stats and access to Double-Edge and Hyper Voice make Mega Salamence a great mixed attacker, which is a big advantage it has over common alternative Mega Evolutions. Draco Meteor is typical in the third slot to deal with Electric-types such as Zapdos and opposing Dragon-types, but Tailwind offers Salamence’s team speed control if this is unnecessary. The given EV spread OHKOes uninvested Tapu Lele with Double-Edge. Tyranitar is a good partner for this set, as it covers Aegislash and Cresselia, which Mega Salamence struggles to deal with. Aegislash is nice defensively given it can switch into all of Salamence’s weaknesses.

Dragon Dance.description: Mega Salamence’s great defenses as well as Intimidate give it an easy time in setting up Dragon Dance. The EVs let Mega Salamence outrun Choice Scarf Tapu Lele at +1, survive Cresselia’s Ice Beam and Tyranitar’s Ice Punch, and maximize the benefit of an Adamant nature. With Double-Edge, they also ensure the move OHKOes Tapu Fini at +1, although the recoil damage associated with the move reduces the value in defensive investment. A Jolly nature with a 252 Atk / 252 Spe spread is an option if you’d prefer more Speed. Redirectors such as Follow Me Clefairy make good partners by keeping Mega Salamence unhindered.

All-out Attacker.description: Mega Metagross's high overall base stats make it solid choice for a Mega Evolution. Its pre-Mega ability in Clear Body also stops Intimidate; you may even wish to delay Mega Evolving for a turn if you anticipate an Intimidate user switching in. Mega Metagross's traits are complemented by allies such as Drizzle Politoed and Pelipper, whose rain dampens Fire moves, and Tapu Lele, whose Psychic Terrain raises Zen Headbutt's damage further. Tapu Koko can also be an effective partner for boosting Thunder Punch and making Bullet Punch less likely to be blocked. Finally, Hydreigon is also a notable partner due to perfect defensive synergy.

Gastrodon.overview:
• One of the main allures of Gastrodon is its ability Storm Drain, which grants it an immunity to Water and acts as a critical Water-type move deterrent that benefits many of its potential teammates. This makes users of Muddy Water like Tapu Fini think twice before using the move, as they risk raising the Special Attack of Gastrodon while also negating non-spread Water-type attacks, such as those from Milotic and Araquanid.

  • Storm Drain often helps against rain teams, as it redirects Water-type moves from teammates so that they can threaten the sweeper. Due to the prevalence of Ludicolo on rain teams, Gastrodon is more of a check than a counter most of the time.

  • Gastrodon has a solid defensive typing that grants it resistances to a variety of types and an immunity to Electric-type moves, leaving only a 4x weakness to Grass. Gastrodon finds itself as a defensive glue on many teams due to the large number of Pokemon it checks, such as Incineroar, Landorus-T, Tapu Koko, Heatran, Nihilego, Zapdos, Mega Gengar, and Mega Manectric.

  • Despite having great Health and Special Defense stats, the poor Defense of Gastrodon limits its tanking potential. It can be heavily damaged by strong physical attackers such as Mega Kangaskhan, Mega Mawile, and Zen Headbutt Mega Metagross or OHKOed by some Z-Moves such as Tectonic Rage from Landorus-T or Excadrill.

  • Gastrodon has low Speed and rarely will outspeed anything even with Tailwind up, though this makes it all the more valuable against Trick Room teams.

  • Gastrodon faces competition when it comes to being a rain check from Ferrothorn, as Ferrothorn doesn’t have to worry about being OHKOed by Ludicolo and can threaten it or its teammates back with moves such as Power Whip. In addition Gastrodon faces competition from Tapu Fini for the bulky Water role on various teams, as Tapu Fini has access to many more moves such as Calm Mind and Heal Pulse and it has more bulk, Speed, and Special Attack.

Bulky Attacker.description:
• Earth Power provides an accurate STAB attack that allows Gastrodon to threaten Pokemon such as Tapu Koko, Incineroar, and Heatran.

  • Ice Beam hits many Pokemon for super effective damage, such as Mega Salamence, Landorus, and Zapdos, and has strong neutral coverage alongside Earth Power.

  • The option of Clear Smog allows Gastrodon to win the one-on-one versus Calm Mind Tapu Fini and allows it to clear away any threatening boosts on opposing Pokemon. This makes Gastrodon less susceptible to becoming setup bait. Recover can give reliable recovery outside of the Wiki Berry to allow Gastrodon to be a nuisance throughout the game. Scald provides another spammable STAB move that has a decent 30% chance to burn, though the other two moves in the set give the necessary coverage to not usually need it.

  • Protect grants Gastrodon the ability to allow its partners to deal with its checks while keeping itself safe.

  • Wiki Berry improves Gastrodon's longevity and grants it a form of recovery should it not run Recover.

  • The EVs on this set guarantee an OHKO on 4 HP / 0 SpD Mega Salamence with Ice Beam and prevents Gastrodon from being 2HKOed by a 252 Atk Adamant Landorus-T Earthquake, a 252 SpA Modest Aegislash-Blade Shadow Ball and a 252 SpA Mega Gengar Shadow Ball

  • 26 Speed IVs allow Gastrodon to underspeed Aegislash by one point to OHKO with Earth Power. Gastrodon can run a Quiet nature with 0 Speed IVs to be more threatening on Trick Room teams or against them.

  • Gastrodon should be switched in on moves it resists or is immune to, especially predicted Water-type moves to use its Water deterring abilities to the fullest. Gastrodon can be kept on the field alongside Pokemon weak to Water-types attacks in order to discourage Water-type attackers from using attacks that could hit its teammate.

  • Gastrodon enjoys Pokemon such as Incineroar and Landorus-T as teammates, as they can weaken physical threats with Intimidate and appreciate Gastrodon's ability to deter Water-types.

  • Gastrodon is often run with Pokemon such as Mega Metagross and Tapu Lele, as both enjoy a rain check, a way to remove Steel-types like Heatran and Mega Metagross lacking Zen Headbutt, and Gastrodon checking metagame threats like Incineroar and Landorus-T.

  • Gastrodon also appreciates Pokemon such as Incineroar, Charizard, and Zapdos with Heat Wave that can threaten Grass-types.

Lopunny.overview:
